Award.AwardTitle: Cochlea-inspired Wireless Compressive Sensing Architectures for Real-time Feedback Control Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Feedback control systems are widely used to control the performance of dynamic systems found in mechanical (e.g., flight control of aircraft) and civil engineering (e.g., response mitigation of buildings during earthquakes). Wireless communication has been proposed as a communication medium for the sensors, actuators and controllers that make up the feedback control system. While wireless communication may dramatically reduce the costs associated with the manufacture of control systems, they simultaneously introduce a new set of technical challenges including power limitations, lower communication speeds and reduced system robustness. This project studies how the human cochlea and the auditory nervous system acquires, communicates and processes acoustic information with the aim of emulating its operational principles in wireless feedback control systems. The power-efficient and real-time processing architectures found in biological neural circuits promise to resolve the long-standing performance bottlenecks associated with wireless telemetry in feedback control applications. The impact this research would have on the US economy is enormous given the prevalence of feedback control systems used daily by society. In addition, the project introduces innovative engineering coursework in bio-inspired engineering and engages middle-school students from underrepresented groups to motivate them to pursue STEM careers.

The overarching goal of the research effort is to apply the methods of neural pulse train coding from the field of neurobiology to resolve the power consumption, speed, and robustness challenges associated with wireless communication in networked feedback control systems. The team will study the sensory neural principles of the mammalian cochlea and will use these principles as the functional basis of an energy-efficient wireless sensor that modulates sensor data into digital pulse train signals communicated directly to the radio frequency spectrum using a code division multiple access (CDMA) communication scheme. The project will also study common neural motifs to serve as functional blocks for the mapping of feedback control laws into complex neural circuits that process the spike train signals generated by the cochlea-inspired wireless sensor nodes. The result will be a biologically inspired wireless feedback control system that implements a compressive sensing strategy at the sensing front-end and processes spike train signals in real-time on the system back-end using neural circuits trained to implement desired feedback control laws. The intellectual significance of the work is that it breaks new ground by adopting the operational principles of biological neural circuits to formalize a new design paradigm for engineered feedback control systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to apply the methods of biological neural circuits (e.g., spike train coding, mechanical-electrical filtering, pattern classification) to address existing performance bottlenecks associated with wireless sensor networks including power consumption, speed, and robustness in smart structure applications. The project focused on studying neural signals found in the central nervous systems to explore new approaches to modulating signals from sensors. A key advancement of the research was the mimicking of the mammalian cochlea where signals are processed by mechanical-electrical filtering; a parallel filter bank architecture with integrate-and-fire elements was developed in hardware to process wireless sensor network signals in a manner similar to a cochlea.  The research also explored neural network architectures to process spike train signals from the filter bank while also developing solid state circuits capable of processing spike trains in hardware.  The work explored application of the research to the monitoring and control of civil infrastructure systems. Specifically, the team explored application of spike train modulated signals to feedback control of multi-story building structures.  To enhance the broader impacts of the work, the team also explored application of the spike train encoded signals to process ultrasonic guided Lamb waves used in thin walled metallic structures for non-destructive evaluation. Furthermore, the band-pass filtering strategies developed in the project led to the team expanding on the project scope to explore the development of passive thin film elements that could serve within a parallel bandpass filter bank for high frequency applications such as those associated with the guided wave methods considered for damage detection in structures.  

The research outcomes establish biology as a fertile area to draw inspiration from for the advancement of novel sensing and control approaches in engineering. Specific outcomes include the advancement of new signal processing methods based on spike train signals commonly found in animal nervous systems to develop compressive and efficient approaches to processing sensing data. The team also translated biologically inspired spike train encoding into low power circuits that contribute to the growing field of neuromorphic computing. These advances will result in more power-efficient and scalable data processing platforms that will enable real-time execution of machine learning algorithms in hardware. While using civil infrastructure systems as the primary application target, the methodologies and technologies developed are applicable to other engineering systems considered for monitoring and control.  To promote the research outcomes, the team wrote a large number of papers published in journals and conference proceedings associated with the fields of electrical engineering and civil engineering. The team also presented aspects of the project in a number of invited presentations at universities. To further enhance the technology transfer potential of the project, the team presented the project in a number of presentations offered to industry leaders.

This project contributed toward the preparation of a future workforce by training engineering graduate students to study how biological systems sense, communicate and process data to inspire novel approaches to the design of monitoring and control systems for engineering applications. The research experiences associated with the project have trained students to be multidisciplinary scholars who are capable of innovating at the interfaces between engineering and scientific disciplines. One participating PhD student completed a doctoral dissertation successfully and joined a company after graduation; a second PhD student is near completion of the dissertation. The team further contributed to the preparation of a future workforce by recruiting undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in engineering to work on the project.  This trained undergraduate students in the basics of advanced research and has inspired those students to go on to pursue graduate degrees after completion of their undergraduate studies.  The team was also an active participant in the Detroit Area Pre-College Engineering Program (DAPCEP) which buses primarily African American middle-school students from Detroit to spend five consecutive Saturdays at the University of Michigan to study science, technology, engineering and mathematical (STEM) topics. The team hosted two offerings of DAPCEP focused on smart structures to inspire the middle-school students to pursue degrees and careers in the STEM fields.
